headline: Google Must Limit Default Contracts to One Year, Judge Rules
summary: Judge Amit Mehta in Washington sided with the US Justice Department on the one year limitation in his final ruling on what changes the search giant must make in the wake of a landmark ruling that the company illegally monopolized online search.  The final judgment will still allow Google to offer its products to Apple Inc. for use in its popular iPhone and pay other electronics makers like Samsung Electronics Co. for default placement.  Mehta noted in his ruling that both Google and the US government said they could work with the one-year limitation on default contracts.

raw.headline: Google Must Limit Default Contracts to One Year, Judge Rules
raw.summary: Judge Amit Mehta in Washington sided with the US Justice Department on the one year limitation in his final ruling on what changes the search giant must make in the wake of a landmark ruling that the company illegally monopolized online search.  The final judgment will still allow Google to offer its products to Apple Inc. for use in its popular iPhone and pay other electronics makers like Samsung Electronics Co. for default placement.  Mehta noted in his ruling that both Google and the US government said they could work with the one-year limitation on default contracts.

headline: The Netflix and Warner Bros. Deal Is Far From a Sure Thing
summary: Netflix  and  Warner Bros. Discovery  have reached a deal—but getting it approved won’t be so easy.  Netflix  on Friday announced that it has agreed to buy Warner Bros. studios and HBO Max once the company completes the previously planned spinoff of its global cable network operations.  The transaction is subject to regulatory approval.

headline: Meta acquires AI-wearables startup Limitless
summary: Meta has acquired AI-wearables startup Limitless, maker of a pendant-style device that records and transcribes ​real-world conversations, as the social media giant doubles down on ‌efforts to build AI-enabled consumer hardware.  Earlier this week, Meta hired ‍longtime Apple  design executive Alan Dye, a move widely seen as sharpening its focus on next-generation devices.  Meta plans to use Limitless' technical capabilities as part of ​its development of next-generation AI-enabled wearables.

headline: eSIM adoption is on the rise thanks to travel and device compatibility
summary: As a technology, eSIM has been around for a decade now. However, global eSIM adoption was around 3% last year and will only cross 5% this year. Despite these figures, analysts, eSIM-providing startups, and investors are bullish about eSIM's upward trajectory, largely thanks to travel.

headline: What Apple's executive departures mean for the iPhone maker
summary: Apple (AAPL) has seen several top executives depart the company recently. Some retired, such as senior vice president of hardware engineering John Ternu (who many expected would succeed Apple CEO Tim Cook), while others were poached by Meta (META), like veteran designers Alan Dye and Billy Sorrentino. Yahoo Finance Tech Editor Dan Howley outlines the details and examines what the executive changes signal about Apple. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: India weighs greater phone-location surveillance; tech giants protest
summary: STORY: India is reviewing a proposal about greater phone-location surveillance.That's according to documents, emails and five sources.The pitch is from the telecom industry to force smartphone firms to enable satellite location tracking.Tech majors, including Apple, Google and Samsung have all opposed the move due to privacy concerns.Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government this week pulled back from forcing smartphone makers to preload a state-run cyber safety app on all devices.Activists and politicians had raised privacy worries about potential snooping.The Modi administration has been concerned for years its agencies don't get precise locations when legal requests are made to telecom firms during investigations.The current system only allows companies to use cellular tower data.That only provides an estimated area location, which can be off by several meters.An email showed a leading Indian telecoms trade body proposed precise user locations should only be provided if authorities order smartphone makers to activate A-GPS technology.It would require location services to always be activated in smartphones with no option for users to disable them.Sources said Apple, Samsung and Alphabet's Google have told New Delhi it shouldn't be mandated.India's IT and home ministries are both analyzing the telecom industry's proposal and didn't respond to Reuters questions.

raw.headline: India weighs greater phone-location surveillance; tech giants protest
raw.summary: STORY: India is reviewing a proposal about greater phone-location surveillance.That's according to documents, emails and five sources.The pitch is from the telecom industry to force smartphone firms to enable satellite location tracking.Tech majors, including Apple, Google and Samsung have all opposed the move due to privacy concerns.Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government this week pulled back from forcing smartphone makers to preload a state-run cyber safety app on all devices.Activists and politicians had raised privacy worries about potential snooping.The Modi administration has been concerned for years its agencies don't get precise locations when legal requests are made to telecom firms during investigations.The current system only allows companies to use cellular tower data.That only provides an estimated area location, which can be off by several meters.An email showed a leading Indian telecoms trade body proposed precise user locations should only be provided if authorities order smartphone makers to activate A-GPS technology.It would require location services to always be activated in smartphones with no option for users to disable them.Sources said Apple, Samsung and Alphabet's Google have told New Delhi it shouldn't be mandated.India's IT and home ministries are both analyzing the telecom industry's proposal and didn't respond to Reuters questions.

headline: Apple May Actually Be Winning the AI Race
summary: Apple  has emerged from the AI doghouse.  The rally follows the botched rollout of  Apple  Intelligence, Apple’s effort to integrate artificial intelligence into its devices.  The big piece of Apple Intelligence was supposed to be a new version of Apple’s digital personal assistant, Siri, that works like the top AI chatbots from OpenAI and  Alphabet  A smarter assistant is something Apple users have craved since Siri first arrived in 2011.

headline: Meta Plans to Shift Spending Away From the Metaverse
summary: Meta Platforms  is planning cuts to the metaverse, an arena Chief Executive  Mark Zuckerberg  once called the future of the company.  The proposed changes are part of Meta’s annual budget planning for 2026, and the company plans to shift spending from the metaverse to artificial-intelligence wearables, according to a person familiar with the matter.  The decision marks a sharp departure from the vision Zuckerberg laid out in 2021, when he changed the name of his company to Meta Platforms, from Facebook, to reflect his belief in growth opportunities in the online digital realm known as the metaverse.

raw.headline: Meta Plans to Shift Spending Away From the Metaverse
raw.summary: Meta Platforms  is planning cuts to the metaverse, an arena Chief Executive  Mark Zuckerberg  once called the future of the company.  The proposed changes are part of Meta’s annual budget planning for 2026, and the company plans to shift spending from the metaverse to artificial-intelligence wearables, according to a person familiar with the matter.  The decision marks a sharp departure from the vision Zuckerberg laid out in 2021, when he changed the name of his company to Meta Platforms, from Facebook, to reflect his belief in growth opportunities in the online digital realm known as the metaverse.

headline: Top Apple Executives to Leave, Adding to Recent Departures
summary: Lisa Jackson, who led sustainability initiatives, will retire in January, and Kate Adams, the company’s general counsel, will retire late next year.
